The weight? 

The weight (P) is a vector quantity since it has intensity, direction and direction, being the product of the mass of a body and the acceleration of gravity exerted on it. Thus, unlike the mass, the weight is a variable value. In the International System (SI), the standard unit of Weight is represented in Newton (N). From this, to calculate the weight of the bodies, the following expression is used: 

P = m.g 

Where, 
P: weight 
m: mass 
g: acceleration of gravity 

Thus, if the gravity value (g) on ​​the surface of planet Earth is Of approximately 9,780 m / s², what is the weight of a 60kg mass body? 

P = m.g 
P = 60 x 9,780 
P = 586,8 N 

Thus the weight of a person of mass 60 kg on planet earth is 586.8 Newton. Therefore, if the gravity value (g) on ​​the surface of the planet Mars is approximately 3,711 m / s², what is the weight of a 60kg mass body?

P = m.g
P = 60 x 3,711 
P = 222.66 N 

Thus the weight of a person with mass 60 kg at mars is 222.66 Newton.

Now, just convert the mass of the body of the earth into mass of the body at mars
M= p / g

Where, 
M: mass 
p: weight 
g: acceleration of gravity 


M = p / g 
M = 222,66 / 9,780 
M = 22.766 kg 

In short: if you have a mass of 60 kg on earth you will have a mass of 22.77 kg on Mars approximately 

The gravitational force applied on your body? 

The same formula is used, knowing that you have a mass of 22.77 kg on Mars and that the acceleration of Mars is 3,711 m / s²
 
P = m.g 
P = 22,77 x 3,711 
P = 84,49 n

You will have the Weight of 84.49 Newton on Mars.
How do we calculate?
